MEAL PRICE INCREASE

In order to conform with USDA’s “Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010”, Scottsboro City Schools is increasing meal prices for 2020-21 school year. Breakfast prices for paid students are $1.50 and for reduced students $.30. Lunch prices for paid students are $2.75 and for reduced students $.40. Parents are highly encouraged to complete a Free and Reduced Meals Application at the beginning of the school year to see if their family may qualify for meal assistance. An application will be sent home with every student on the first day of school. However, parents only have to complete one application per household. Parents may apply online at www.paypams.com/ApplyNowScottsboro. If you have any questions, you may contact Ms. Melva Rodgers, Child Nutrition Director at 256-218-2124 or merodgers@scottsboroschools.net.

post_text: The State of Alabama has announced it will spend $103 million in Federal Funding on a program called Alabama Broadband Connectivity (ABC) for Students. This will provide vouchers to families of students who receive free or reduced price meals in schools for the installation of broadband service. This applies to both Virtual and Traditional Learning Students. In order to ensure you qualify for the broadband connectivity, please make sure that you complete the 2020-21 Free and Reduced Meals Application in a timely manner at www.paypams.com/ApplyNowScottsboro. If you use this link to apply online, you will NOT need to complete a paper application at the beginning of school. Only one application per household (with all children listed) is necessary. Scottsboro City Schools will provide more information about ABC for Students as it becomes available from the State of Alabama.

I attended a meeting yesterday with a group called Cyber Huntsville. During the meeting, the head of the new Alabama School of Cyber Technology and Engineering spoke. The ASCTE is Alabama's only fully public, residential high school for students seeking advanced studies in math, science, engineering, and cyber technology. Although residential housing is available, those near Huntsville can commute. Tuition for ASCTE is free. Through the month of March 2020, the school be accepting applications for its first set of students in the Fall. In the Fall of 2020, ASCTE will welcome its first classes and if you are interested, I would encourage parents and students to visit their website at www.ascte.org. The website should give you all the information that you need in order to make an informed decision concerning applying, etc.

Warmest Regards,

Dr. Reyes

post_text: DeAndre Walker is a student at Scottsboro High School in Mrs. Brogdon's classroom. The "Wildcat Perk" coffee shop opened at SHS in January of this year. Mrs. Brogdon's class runs the coffee shop in the mornings before school and during second chance breakfast. The students assist in making the coffee, getting ice, taking orders, and serving the students coffee. DeAndre's passion has always been to be a barista or run a coffee shop. He said he was "living his dream" by doing this everyday. The students now know DeAndre by name and talk to him daily. He remembers their order and works so hard to please the customers. DeAndre is punctual, as he is here early to open the coffee shop every morning. He always has a smile on his face and is humble with every task that he is given. DeAndre said that he learned his work ethic from his mom and sister. He enjoys drawing, reading, and playing video games when he is not at school, but hopes that he can get a job making coffee or running his own shop eventually.

Just a reminder that the sub workshop is tomorrow. This will be the last sub workshop of the calendar year.

The sub workshop will be at the Paige Administration Building Wednesday morning from 9 AM to 11 AM.

Anyone who attends and follows through with paperwork requirements could be added to the sub list as early as the November board meeting.
